products.name: Amaranth Greens
products.ingredients: Shade-dried amaranth leaves, naturally rich in minerals, amino acids, and antioxidants.
products.storage: Store in a cool, dry, and dark place. Always keep tightly sealed. Avoid prolonged heat and humidity.
products.shelfLife: For best potency, use within 12–18 months.
products.shortDescription: Shade-dried Amaranthus leaves, known as bledo, rooted in Mesoamerican food tradition for skin vitality and whole-body nourishment.
products.description:
The vibrant leaves of Amaranthus spp., known as 'bledo' in Honduran tradition, represent a sacred legacy of Mesoamerican nourishment. Hand-gathered from wild fields, these greens carry the ancestral wisdom of indigenous harvesters who have valued them for generations. 

Celebrated for their vitality-sustaining properties and deep cultural roots, they are carefully dried to preserve their nutritional power. Offered in whole-leaf form, free from modern processing or contaminants.
howToUse: Culinary Preparation (Cooked Greens): Thoroughly wash Amaranth greens and remove tough lower stems, keeping only tender leaves and upper stems. Bring a large pot of salted water to a rolling boil. Add Amaranth greens and boil for 2-5 minutes until tender but still bright green. Drain immediately in a colander. Serve warm, drizzled with extra virgin olive oil, fresh lemon juice, and sea salt.

Sautéed Preparation: After blanching (as above), heat olive oil in a pan over medium heat. Add chopped onion and garlic, sauté until fragrant. Add blanched Amaranth greens, stir-fry for 2-3 minutes. Season with salt, pepper, and a squeeze of lemon. Serve warm as a nutritious side dish.
In Soups & Stews: Add fresh Amaranth greens directly to soups, stews, or curries during the last 5-10 minutes of cooking. The greens will wilt and add nutritious depth to your dish.
Nutritional Tea (Mild Infusion): Place a handful of fresh Amaranth greens in boiling water for 2-3 minutes. Strain and drink the mild green infusion for its mineral and vitamin content.
Nutritional Benefits: Amaranth greens are exceptionally rich in iron, calcium, vitamins A, C, and K, protein, and fiber—making them one of the most nutritious leafy greens available.
processingMethod: Selective Harvesting — Herbs are hand-picked at peak maturity, with care to protect plant populations and ecosystems.
Manual Cleaning — Unwanted parts like dirt and dry leaves are removed; useful portions are sorted for quality.
Drying Setup — Delicate herbs are tied in small bunches or spread thinly to allow natural airflow.
Shade Drying — Materials dry slowly in a cool, shaded space to preserve aroma, color, and beneficial properties.
Storage — Once fully dry, herbs are trimmed and sealed in airtight containers to maintain freshness and potency.
products.disclaimer: FOR TRADITIONAL USE ONLY. This product is not intended to diagnose, treat, cure, or prevent any disease. Discontinue use if irritation occurs. Keep out of reach of children. Consult a healthcare professional before use if pregnant or nursing. Individual results may vary.

products.ingredients: Batana oil, water, plant-based conditioners, natural fragrance.
products.storage: Store in a cool, dry, and dark place. Always keep tightly sealed. Avoid prolonged heat and humidity.
products.shelfLife: For best potency, use within 12–18 months.
products.shortDescription: Deep-conditioning batana oil blend, hand crafted by Miskito from Elaeis oleifera palms. A ancestral hair nourishment used to restore, soften and protect.
products.description: A deep-conditioning ritual rooted in Miskito tradition. Crafted with authentic Batana Oil from the wild Elaeis oleifera palms of La Mosquitia, Honduras, this formula transforms hair through ancestral nourishment. Used for generations to restore, soften, and protect, it delivers penetrating moisture while honoring the wisdom of the rainforest. From the hands of Miskito artisans to your hair care routine, it bridges ancient practice with modern performance.
howToUse: Deep Conditioning Treatment: After shampooing, gently squeeze excess water from your hair. Apply a generous amount of conditioner to your hair, working from mid-lengths to ends. For damaged or coarse hair, apply a small amount to roots as well. Use a wide-tooth comb to distribute evenly through every strand, ensuring full coverage. Leave on for 3–5 minutes to allow the ancestral Batana Oil formula to penetrate and restore your hair's natural structure.

Intensive Repair (Weekly): For severely damaged, color-treated, or chemically processed hair, apply conditioner to clean, damp hair and cover with a shower cap. Leave on for 15–30 minutes, using the warmth from a towel or shower steam to enhance penetration. Rinse thoroughly with cool water to seal the cuticle and lock in moisture.
Leave-In Treatment (Extra-Dry Hair): Apply a small amount to the ends of towel-dried hair as a leave-in treatment. Do not rinse. Style as usual.
For Frizz Control & Shine: Use as your regular conditioner 2–3 times per week, or daily for very dry or textured hair types.
Rinse thoroughly with warm water. For maximum benefits, pair with Batana Oil Hair Wash.
processingMethod: Forest Sourcing — Materials are gathered from the rainforest, including traditionally prepared Batana Oil made through ancestral Miskito methods.
Thermal Softening — The base components are gently warmed and blended to create a smooth, workable mixture.
Artisanal Integration — Batana Oil is incorporated using slow, controlled heat to preserve its natural restorative qualities.
Cooling & Thickening — The mixture is allowed to cool gradually, developing its creamy texture without industrial accelerants.
Finishing & Storage — The conditioner is settled, refined, and stored in clean containers to maintain its freshness and nourishing character.
products.disclaimer: FOR TRADITIONAL USE ONLY. This product is not intended to diagnose, treat, cure, or prevent any disease. Discontinue use if irritation occurs. Keep out of reach of children. Consult a healthcare professional before use if pregnant or nursing. Individual results may vary.

products.shortDescription: Miskito-crafted hair shampoo with authentic Batana Oil from wild Elaeis oleifera in La Mosquitia, Honduras. A gentle cleansing that supports stronger, softer hair.
products.description: A gentle cleansing ritual rooted in Miskito tradition. Crafted with authentic Batana Oil from the wild Elaeis oleifera palms of La Mosquitia, Honduras, this shampoo transforms hair washing into an ancestral nourishment ritual. Used for generations to cleanse without stripping natural oils, it delivers follicle restoration and scalp nourishment while honoring the wisdom of the rainforest. From the hands of Miskito artisans to your daily routine, it bridges ancient practice with modern performance. Sulfate-free formula respects your hair's natural moisture balance.
howToUse: Daily Cleansing: Wet hair thoroughly with warm water. Apply a generous amount of shampoo to scalp and hair. Massage gently using fingertips (not nails) in circular motions for 1–2 minutes to create a rich lather and stimulate blood flow. Work through from roots to ends, ensuring full coverage. Rinse thoroughly with warm water.

Double Wash (for oily hair or product buildup): Apply a small amount for the first wash to remove surface oils and dirt. Rinse. Apply a second time and massage for 2–3 minutes to deeply cleanse the scalp. Rinse thoroughly.
Scalp Treatment Wash: For dry or flaky scalp, massage shampoo into scalp and leave on for 3–5 minutes before rinsing. The Batana Oil will nourish and soothe irritation.
Color-Treated Hair: Use lukewarm water instead of hot to preserve color. Apply shampoo gently without vigorous scrubbing.
Best Results: Follow with Batana Oil Hair Conditioner for maximum benefits. Use 2–3 times per week, or daily for very oily hair types.
For Maximum Growth: Massage scalp during washing for at least 2 minutes to stimulate circulation.
processingMethod: Forest Sourcing — Authentic Batana Oil is gathered from wild Elaeis oleifera palms in La Mosquitia through traditional Miskito methods.
Base Preparation — Plant-based cleansing agents derived from coconut and other natural sources are combined with purified water.
Oil Integration — Raw Batana Oil is carefully emulsified into the cleansing base using gentle heat and natural emulsifiers to create a stable, nourishing formula.
Botanical Addition — Supporting herbs and natural extracts are infused to enhance scalp health and fragrance.
Quality Testing — Each batch is tested for consistency, pH balance (5.0–6.0 for hair health), and cleansing efficacy.
Bottling — Shampoo is filled into pump bottles for convenient, hygienic dispensing.
products.disclaimer: FOR TRADITIONAL USE ONLY. This product is not intended to diagnose, treat, cure, or prevent any disease. Discontinue use if irritation occurs. Keep out of reach of children. Consult a healthcare professional before use if pregnant or nursing. Individual results may vary.

products.name: Batana Oil True Soap Bar
products.ingredients: Saponified batana oil, natural glycerin, plant-based oils, purified water, natural fragrance
products.storage: Store in a cool, dry, and dark place. Always keep tightly sealed. Avoid prolonged heat and humidity.
products.shelfLife: For best potency, use within 12–18 months.
products.shortDescription: Handmade artisanal Miskito batana oil soap from wild Elaeis oleifera kernels in La Mosquitia. A daily wash for soft hair and skin, rooted in traditional care.
products.description: An artisanal cleansing bar rooted in Miskito tradition. Handcrafted with 100% saponified Batana Oil from wild Elaeis oleifera palm kernels of La Mosquitia, Honduras, this true soap offers gentle, nourishing cleansing for hair, skin, and body. Unlike commercial detergent bars, this is genuine soap made through traditional saponification — preserving the natural glycerin and skin-loving properties of pure Batana Oil. Used for generations by Miskito families as an all-in-one wash, it cleanses without stripping natural moisture. From rainforest to ritual, each bar carries ancestral wisdom into modern self-care.
howToUse: Hair Wash: Wet hair thoroughly. Rub the soap bar directly onto scalp and hair in circular motions to create lather, or lather in hands first and apply to hair. Massage scalp for 1–2 minutes. Work lather through to ends. Rinse thoroughly with warm water. Follow with conditioner if desired. Use 2–3 times per week.

Body Wash: Wet skin in shower or bath. Lather soap between hands or use a washcloth. Apply lather to body, massaging gently. Rinse thoroughly. The natural glycerin will leave skin soft without residue.
Face Wash: Wet face with warm water. Lather soap in hands and apply gently to face in circular motions. Avoid eye area. Rinse thoroughly with cool water. Pat dry. Use morning and night.
Shaving: Wet skin with warm water. Lather soap generously on shaving area using a brush or hands. Shave as usual. Rinse thoroughly. The natural oils will provide glide and post-shave moisture.
Hand Soap: Keep at sink. Lather between hands with water. Rinse clean.
Extend Bar Life: After each use, place on a well-draining soap dish away from direct water spray. Allow to air dry completely between uses.
processingMethod: Oil Preparation — Authentic Batana Oil is sourced from Miskito harvesters who cold-press wild Elaeis oleifera kernels from La Mosquitia rainforest.
Lye Solution — A precise lye (sodium hydroxide) solution is prepared with purified water, measured for exact saponification ratios.
Saponification — Batana Oil is slowly heated and combined with lye solution. The mixture is stirred continuously as it saponifies (converts oil into soap and natural glycerin).
Supporting Oils — Additional plant-based oils are blended in to enhance lather, conditioning, and skin feel.
Molding — The thick soap mixture is poured into traditional molds and allowed to set for 24–48 hours.
Curing — Bars are removed from molds and cured in ventilated racks for 4–6 weeks. This aging process hardens the bars, completes saponification, and develops a mild, skin-friendly pH.
Trimming & Packaging — Cured bars are hand-trimmed, inspected for quality, and packaged in eco-friendly boxes.

products.shortDescription: Shade-dried Bay Leaves (Laurus nobilis) from Honduras, valued in traditional herbal practice for respiratory ease, digestive comfort, and aromatic vitality.
products.description:
The aromatic leaves of Laurus nobilis, called 'laurel' in local kitchens, have seasoned both traditional remedies and ancestral recipes for centuries. Carefully wild-harvested from Honduras' highland forests, these leaves carry the earthy essence of generations of herbal wisdom. 

Revered for their cleansing aroma and ceremonial significance, they are patiently shade-dried to preserve their volatile oils. Offered whole and pure, free from artificial preservatives or treatments.
howToUse: Herbal Infusion (Tea): Place 2-3 dried bay leaves (or 4-6 fresh leaves) in a teacup or teapot. Pour 1 cup (240ml) of freshly boiled water over the leaves. Do NOT boil the leaves directly—add to water after removing from heat. Cover and steep for 5-10 minutes. Remove bay leaves and drink warm. For a milder flavor, steep for 5 minutes; for stronger medicinal properties, steep up to 10 minutes.
For Digestive Comfort: Drink 1 cup of bay leaf tea 30 minutes after meals to support healthy digestion, reduce bloating, and ease gas. Use 2-3 times daily as needed.

For Respiratory Support: Prepare bay leaf tea as above and inhale the aromatic steam before drinking. The volatile oils help clear congestion and support respiratory comfort. Drink 2-3 cups daily during seasonal challenges.
Culinary Use: Add 1-2 whole dried bay leaves to soups, stews, sauces, and rice dishes during cooking. Remove leaves before serving, as they remain tough and sharp even after cooking.
Flavor Enhancement: Bay leaf tea can be enhanced with honey, lemon, cinnamon, or ginger for added flavor and complementary benefits.

products.shortDescription: Pure dried Bitter Melon (Momordica charantia), known as cundeamor, traditionally used for digestive comfort, skin balance, and overall vitality.
products.description:
The distinctive fruit of Momordica charantia, known locally as 'cundeamor,' embodies the powerful principle that potency often resides in challenging flavors. Wild-harvested from Honduran vines, this cubed and dried fruit carries generations of indigenous wisdom about nature's balancing forces. 

Respected for its uncompromising character and traditional applications, it is prepared using methods passed down through ancestral knowledge. Offered in its pure, unadulterated form, free from sweeteners or processing.
howToUse: Herbal Tea (Leaf or Whole Plant): Place 1-2 teaspoons (3-5g) of dried Bitter Melon herb in a teapot or cup. Pour 1 cup (240ml) of boiling water over the herb. Cover and steep for 10-15 minutes. Strain and drink 1 cup 2-3 times daily, preferably 30 minutes before meals for traditional blood sugar support.

Decoction (For Stronger Effect): Combine 2 tablespoons (10g) of dried Bitter Melon herb with 2 cups (500ml) of water in a pot. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 15-20 minutes. Strain and divide into 2-3 servings throughout the day.

For Traditional Diabetes Support: Consume Bitter Melon tea consistently 2-3 times daily before meals. Traditional use suggests ongoing consumption for blood sugar balance. Monitor blood sugar levels and consult with healthcare provider if taking diabetes medication.
For Digestive & Liver Health: Drink 1 cup of Bitter Melon tea after meals to support digestive function and traditional liver wellness.
Taste Note: Bitter Melon is notably bitter. You may sweeten with honey or stevia, or combine with other herbs like mint or ginger to improve palatability.

products.shortDescription: Cardo Santo (Cnicus benedictus), shade-dried and rooted in sacred herbal tradition, valued for digestive balance, appetite support, and lactation wellness.
products.description:
The thorny leaves of Cnicus benedictus, known as 'cardo santo' or 'blessed thistle,' have journeyed from Mediterranean monasteries to Honduras' highland gardens as a plant of sacred herbalism. Wild-harvested from naturalized stands, these leaves carry centuries of European and adapted Central American knowledge about bitter tonics and traditional wellness. 

Revered for their protective spines and time-honored digestive applications, they are shade-dried to preserve their sesquiterpene lactone content. Offered chopped, free from pesticides or monastery garden romanticism that obscures botanical reality.
howToUse: Herbal Infusion (Tea): Measure 1-3 teaspoons (1.5-3g) of dried Blessed Thistle herb into a teacup or teapot. Pour 1 cup (240ml) of boiling water over the herb. Cover and steep for 5-10 minutes. Strain and drink 2 cups daily, preferably 30 minutes to 1 hour before meals for digestive support.

For Digestive Health & Appetite Stimulation: Drink 1 cup of Blessed Thistle tea 30-60 minutes before main meals. The bitter compounds traditionally stimulate digestive secretions and support healthy appetite.
For Liver Support & Detoxification: Consume 2 cups of Blessed Thistle tea daily, one in the morning and one in the evening, to support traditional liver function and gentle detoxification.

For Lactation Support (Traditional Use): Nursing mothers may drink 2-3 cups of Blessed Thistle tea daily to traditionally support milk production. Consult with healthcare provider before use during lactation.
Flavor Tip: Blessed Thistle is intensely bitter. Combine with Peppermint leaves and Fennel seeds to balance the bitterness while maintaining therapeutic properties. Sweeten with honey if desired.

products.shortDescription: Shade-dried Golden Shower Tree pods (Cassia fistula), or caña fístula, rooted in Honduran tradition for digestion and natural cleansing support.
products.description:
The distinctive seed pods of Cassia fistula, known locally as 'caña fístula,' dangle like natural medicine cabinets from Honduras' tropical canopies. Wild-harvested at peak maturity, these pods carry centuries of indigenous knowledge about gentle yet effective traditional wellness practices. 

Revered for their time-honored uses and subtle potency, they are carefully dried to preserve their inner pulp and seeds. Offered whole, allowing traditional preparation methods to unlock their ancestral benefits, free from chemical treatment or artificial processing.
howToUse: Herbal Tea (Pod Pieces): Break 2-3 Cassia pod segments (approximately 5-10cm total length) into smaller pieces. Place in a pot with 2-3 cups (500-750ml) of water. Bring to a boil, then reduce heat and simmer for 20-30 minutes until water turns golden-brown. Strain and drink 1 cup 1-2 times daily.

For Gentle Digestive Support: Drink 1 cup of Cassia pod tea in the morning or evening to support healthy bowel movements and digestive regularity. Start with a small amount to assess individual tolerance.
For Traditional Cleansing: Prepare Cassia pod tea as directed and consume 1 cup daily for 3-7 days as part of a traditional gentle cleansing routine. Ensure adequate hydration throughout the day.
Traditional Note: Cassia pods have been used for centuries in Ayurvedic and traditional medicine systems for their mild purgative properties and digestive support.
Caution: Use moderately. Excessive consumption may cause digestive discomfort.

products.shortDescription: Wild-harvested Cat's Claw (Uncaria tomentosa), known as uña de gato, traditionally valued for natural defense, joint comfort, digestive balance, and resilience.
products.description:
The formidable vine of Uncaria tomentosa, known locally as 'uña de gato,' climbs through Central American ethnobotanical history with its hook-like thorns and resilient spirit. Wild-harvested from Honduras' rainforests, this chopped bark carries generations of indigenous knowledge about the forest's protective wisdom. 

Revered for its traditional uses and symbolic strength, it is harvested with deep respect for the plant's lifecycle. Offered in its authentic, unencapsulated form, free from fillers or synthetic enhancements.
howToUse: Decoction (Traditional Preparation): Measure 5-10g (approximately 2-3 teaspoons) of dried Cat's Claw root bark and place in a pot with 300-500ml (1.5-2 cups) of water. Bring to a rolling boil, then reduce heat to low and simmer gently for 15-20 minutes. Remove from heat, cover, and let steep for an additional 10 minutes. Strain through a fine-mesh sieve. Drink 1-2 cups daily, divided into 2-3 servings.

For Immune Support & Inflammation: Consume Cat's Claw decoction consistently, 1-2 cups daily. Traditional use suggests ongoing consumption for best results. May be taken between meals for optimal absorption.
For Joint Health & Comfort: Drink 1 cup of Cat's Claw tea 2-3 times daily to traditionally support joint mobility and ease discomfort associated with occasional inflammation.
For Digestive Wellness: Take Cat's Claw decoction 30 minutes before meals to support traditional digestive health and soothe the gastrointestinal tract.
Taste Note: Cat's Claw has a bitter, earthy flavor. Sweeten with honey or blend with mint leaves for improved taste.

products.shortDescription: Wild-harvested Smilax root, also known as cocolmeca, traditionally valued for digestive comfort, skin vitality, and natural cleansing support.
products.description:
The gnarled roots of Smilax species, known locally as 'cocolmeca' or 'zarzaparrilla,' burrow deep into Honduran soil as keepers of ancestral vitality. Wild-harvested with respect for the plant's underground network, these roots embody generations of Mesoamerican knowledge about purification and restoration. 

Revered for their bitter strength and traditional significance in indigenous wellness practices, they are carefully processed to preserve their dense, woody character. Offered in cut pieces, free from fumigation or chemical extraction.
howToUse: Strong Decoction (Traditional Preparation): Take a generous handful (approximately 30-40g) of Cocolmeca root pieces and place in a large pot with half a gallon (approximately 2 liters) of water. Bring to a rolling boil, then reduce heat and simmer vigorously for 20-30 minutes. Remove from heat and allow to steep for an additional 10-20 minutes. Strain the liquid, pressing down on root pieces to extract maximum benefits. Drink 2-3 cups daily.

For Blood Purification & Detoxification (Traditional Use): Consume 2-3 cups of Cocolmeca decoction daily for 7-14 days as part of a traditional cleansing protocol. The strong infusion traditionally supports lymphatic drainage and blood purification.
For Skin Health: Drink Cocolmeca tea consistently, 2-3 cups daily, to traditionally support clear, healthy skin from within. Results may be noticed after 2-4 weeks of consistent use.
Reuse Roots: Cocolmeca roots can be reused 2-3 times. Simply add fresh water and simmer again for 20 minutes. The subsequent batches will be milder but still beneficial.
Traditional Note: Cocolmeca (Sarsaparilla) has been used for centuries throughout Latin America as a powerful blood tonic and purifying agent.

products.shortDescription: Wild-harvested Contribo vine (Aristolochia spp), rooted in Central American tradition for cleansing support, digestive ease, and resilient energy.
products.description:
The powerful vine of Aristolochia species, known locally as 'contribo' or 'guaco,' climbs through Central American ethnobotanical tradition with formidable reputation and ancestral authority. Wild-harvested from Honduras' forest margins, this plant carries indigenous wisdom about nature's most potent protective forces. 

Respected for its traditional uses and uncompromising character, it is harvested with ceremonial caution and deep knowledge of the plant's spirit. Offered chopped, in its pure botanical form, free from dilution or synthetic modification.
howToUse: Herbal Infusion (Cold Soak Method - Preferred): Place 1-2 pieces (approximately 5-10cm) of dried Contribo vine in a cup of room-temperature water. Allow to soak for 30-60 minutes. Remove vine pieces and drink the infused water. Use once daily or as needed.

Herbal Tea (Hot Preparation): Place 1-2 pieces of Contribo vine in a teapot with 1-2 cups (240-500ml) of water. Bring to a gentle simmer (do not boil vigorously) for 5-10 minutes. Remove from heat, cover, and steep for 10 minutes. Strain and drink 1 cup as needed.
For Flu, Colds & Respiratory Support: Drink 1 cup of Contribo infusion at the first sign of cold or flu symptoms. May be consumed 1-2 times daily during seasonal challenges.
For Digestive Comfort: Take Contribo tea 30 minutes before meals to support healthy digestion, ease indigestion, and stimulate appetite.

products.shortDescription: Holy wood (Bursera graveolens), wildcrafted and burned across the Americas for spiritual cleansing, aromatic calm, and natural protection.
products.description:
The sacred wood of Bursera graveolens, called 'palo santo' or 'holy wood,' releases sweet, resinous smoke that has cleared ceremonial space across South and Central America for millennia. Wild-harvested from naturally fallen branches in Honduras' dry tropical forests, this wood carries indigenous Andean and adapted regional knowledge about spiritual cleansing and aromatic healing. 

Revered for its limonene-rich profile and traditional applications in meditation and sacred ritual, it is naturally aged to concentrate its essential oils. Offered in wood sticks or chips, free from artificial scents or premature harvest that disrespects the tree's lifecycle.
howToUse: Aromatic Incense (Primary Traditional Use): Hold a Palo Santo stick at a 45-degree angle and light the tip using a match or lighter. Allow it to burn for 30-60 seconds, then gently blow out the flame, allowing the stick to smolder and release fragrant smoke. Place in a heat-safe dish or holder. The smoke traditionally purifies spaces, clears negative energy, and promotes spiritual grounding.

For Space Clearing & Purification: Walk through your space with smoldering Palo Santo, directing smoke into corners and doorways to cleanse the energy. Use during meditation, yoga practice, or before important events.

For Meditation & Relaxation: Light Palo Santo and allow the aromatic smoke to fill your meditation space. The grounding, sweet, woody aroma supports deep relaxation, mental clarity, and spiritual connection.

Palo Santo Tea (Rare, Alternative Use): Small wood chips can be simmered in water for 10-15 minutes to create a mild aromatic tea. Strain and drink 1 cup for internal cleansing. However, incense use is the primary traditional method.

Sustainability Note: Only use Palo Santo from naturally fallen branches. Never harvest from living trees. Our Palo Santo is ethically sourced from fallen wood, allowing the tree's resin to fully develop over 4-10 years.

products.description:
The legendary inner bark of Tabebuia species, known as 'lapacho' or 'pau d'arco,' emerges from Honduras' forests as one of South America's most celebrated botanicals. Wild-harvested with respect for the tree's slow growth and limited regeneration, this bark carries indigenous Amazonian and adapted Central American knowledge about immune resilience and natural defense. 

Revered for its traditional applications in wellness support and its complex naphthoquinone content, it is carefully processed to preserve the inner cambium layer where active compounds concentrate. Offered in shredded bark pieces, free from synthetic lapachol or pharmaceutical extraction.
howToUse: Herbal Decoction (Inner Bark): Place 2-3 teaspoons (10-15g) of Pau D'Arco inner bark pieces in a pot with 3-4 cups (750ml-1L) of water. Bring to a rolling boil, then reduce heat and simmer vigorously for 20-30 minutes until water reduces by one-third. Remove from heat, cover, and steep for an additional 15 minutes. Strain thoroughly and drink 2-3 cups daily, divided throughout the day.

For Immune Support & Wellness: Consume Pau D'Arco decoction consistently, 2-3 cups daily, to traditionally support immune function, promote overall vitality, and maintain wellness. Best results with ongoing use over several weeks.

products.shortDescription: Authentic batana oil sourced from La Mosquitia, Honduras, crafted by Miskito hands from wild Elaeis oleifera palms for hair, skin, and daily beard care support.
products.description: The ancestral treasure of the Miskito people. Raw Batana Oil is cold-pressed from wild Elaeis oleifera palm kernels deep in the rainforests of La Mosquitia, Honduras. For centuries, Miskito women have relied on this sacred oil to nourish, restore, and protect their hair — a ritual passed down through generations. Unrefined and pure, it retains all its natural nutrients, antioxidants, and fatty acids. From the hands of rainforest harvesters to your daily routine, this oil bridges ancient wisdom with modern hair care.
howToUse: Hair Treatment: Apply a generous amount to dry or damp hair, focusing on the scalp and ends. Massage gently to stimulate circulation. Leave on for 30 minutes to overnight for deep conditioning. Wash with a gentle shampoo. Use 2–3 times per week for best results.

Scalp Massage: Warm a small amount between your palms. Massage into the scalp using circular motions for 5–10 minutes to promote blood flow and hair growth. Leave on for at least 1 hour before washing.
Beard Care: Apply 2–3 drops to damp beard after cleansing. Work through from roots to tips. Style as usual. Use daily for soft, manageable facial hair.
Skin Moisturizer: Apply a thin layer to clean skin, especially on dry areas, elbows, and heels. Massage until absorbed. Use morning and night.
Pre-Shampoo Treatment: Apply to dry hair 30 minutes before shampooing to protect hair from damage during washing.
Leave-In Treatment: Apply a small amount to the ends of damp hair after washing. Do not rinse. Style as usual.
processingMethod: Harvest — Wild Elaeis oleifera palm fruits are hand-harvested by Miskito communities from pristine rainforest groves in La Mosquitia.
Fermentation — Fruits are traditionally fermented in clay pots for 7–10 days to soften the kernel and develop the oil's characteristic earthy aroma.
Kernel Extraction — Fermented fruits are cracked open by hand to extract the nutrient-rich kernels.
Cold Pressing — Kernels are cold-pressed using traditional wooden presses to extract pure oil without heat, preserving all natural compounds.
Settling & Filtration — Oil is allowed to settle naturally for several days, then filtered through natural fibers to remove impurities.
Packaging — Raw oil is stored in amber glass jars to protect from light degradation and maintain freshness.

products.shortDescription: Hoja de malanga (Colocasia esculenta), an iron-rich Caribbean leaf valued in tradition for blood vitality and gentle nourishment.
products.description:
The broad, heart-shaped leaves of Colocasia esculenta, known as 'malanga' or 'quequisque,' have nourished Polynesian, African, and Caribbean cultures for millennia before taking root in Honduran soil. Wild-harvested from humid lowland plantings, these leaves carry ancestral wisdom about mineral-rich nutrition and traditional food security. 

Celebrated for their calcium oxalate management through proper preparation and their role in sustaining communities, they are shade-dried to preserve their nutrient density. Offered chopped, with traditional preparation knowledge essential, free from chemical fertilizers or pesticide residues.
howToUse: Culinary Preparation (Cooked Greens - Primary Use): Taro/Malanga leaves MUST be cooked thoroughly to neutralize calcium oxalate crystals, which can cause mouth irritation if consumed raw. Wash leaves thoroughly and remove tough stems. Boil in salted water for 20-30 minutes until very tender. Drain and use in soups, stews, curries, or stir-fries. The cooked leaves are highly nutritious and commonly used in Caribbean and African cuisine.

In Soups & Stews (Callaloo): Add thoroughly cooked Taro leaves to traditional dishes like Callaloo, adding them during the last 20-30 minutes of cooking. The leaves provide rich, earthy flavor and nutritional depth.

Medicinal Tea (Rare, Use Caution): Due to calcium oxalate content, tea from Taro leaves is not commonly recommended. If preparing, boil leaves for at least 20 minutes and strain very well. Use sparingly and only after proper cooking.
Important Caution: NEVER consume raw Taro leaves. Always cook thoroughly. Raw leaves contain calcium oxalate crystals that cause severe mouth and throat irritation.

products.description:
The aromatic leaves of Thuja spp., the sacred cedar honored by indigenous North and Central American cultures, grow in Honduras' cooler highland forests. Hand-picked with ceremonial respect for the tree's enduring presence, these leaves carry spiritual and practical significance across generations. 

Traditionally used for purification and respiratory wellness, they are harvested to maintain their ethereal essence, resinous potency, and concentrated volatile oils.
traditionalUses: Aids emotional balance and mental clarity
howToUse: Herbal Infusion (Mild Tea): Place 1/2 to 1 teaspoon (2-3g) of dried Thuja leaves in a teapot or cup. Pour 1 cup (240ml) of boiling water over the leaves. Cover and steep for 5-10 minutes. Strain well and drink 1 cup daily. Do not exceed recommended amounts.

For Immune Support (Traditional Use): Drink 1 cup of Thuja tea daily during seasonal challenges to traditionally support immune function and respiratory wellness. Traditional Native American use for colds and infections.
For Respiratory Support: Consume Thuja tea 1-2 times daily to traditionally support respiratory comfort and ease congestion.
Steam Inhalation (For Congestion): Place a handful of Thuja leaves in a bowl of very hot water. Drape a towel over your head and inhale the aromatic steam for 5-10 minutes to clear sinus congestion.

External Use (Topical): Prepare a strong Thuja tea and apply topically to skin conditions such as warts, fungal infections, or minor skin irritations. Traditional external use is more common than internal consumption.

products.shortDescription: Guarumo (Cecropia spp), a trusted Central American tree brewed for cardiovascular balance, metabolic ease, and respiratory comfort.
products.description:
The palmately lobed leaves of Cecropia species, known as 'guarumo' or 'trumpet tree,' crown Honduras' secondary forests where they provide vital habitat for sloths and ants in symbiotic relationship. Wild-harvested from these ecological guardian trees, the leaves carry indigenous Central and South American knowledge about respiratory support and cardiovascular wellness. 

Revered for their traditional applications in blood pressure management and their role in forest regeneration, they are shade-dried to preserve their chlorogenic acid and flavonoid content. Offered whole or cut, free from agricultural chemicals or habitat-destructive harvesting practices.
howToUse: Herbal Infusion (Tea): Place 1-2 teaspoons (5-8g) of dried Trumpet Tree leaves in a teapot or cup. Pour 1 cup (240ml) of boiling water over the leaves. Cover and steep for 10-15 minutes. Strain and drink 1-2 cups daily.

For Blood Pressure Support (Primary Traditional Use): Drink 1-2 cups of Trumpet Tree leaf tea daily to traditionally support healthy blood pressure levels and cardiovascular wellness. Traditional use throughout Central and South America for hypertension.
For Blood Sugar Balance: Consume 1 cup of Trumpet Tree tea before meals to traditionally support healthy blood sugar metabolism. Use consistently for best results.
For Respiratory Health: Drink Trumpet Tree tea 2-3 times daily to traditionally support respiratory comfort, ease cough, and promote clear breathing.

Traditional Note: Trumpet Tree (Cecropia) is widely used throughout the Amazon and Central America, particularly for cardiovascular and metabolic support. The tree is also home to ant colonies in a fascinating symbiotic relationship.
